Authors:
Michael David Pirie, E.G.H. Oliver, Berit Gehrke, Lukas
Heringer, Ana Mugrabi de Kuppler, Nicholas Le Maitre, Dirk
Bellstedt
Title:
Underestimated regional species diversity in the Cape
Floristic Region revealed by phylogenetic analysis of the Erica
abietina/viscaria-clade (Ericaceae)
Journal: Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society
Keywords:
Biodiversity hotspot; Cape Floristic Region; Cape
Peninsula; endemism; External Transcribed Spacer; phylogeny; species
delimitation; Table Mountain National Park
Abstract:
As one of the largest genera of flowering plants, the
richness of species of Erica (Ericaceae) is all the more remarkable
because over 80% of the >800 are endemic to the smallest floral
kingdom, the Cape Floristic Region (CFR) of South Africa. Within the
CFR, pockets of narrowly endemic taxa rub shoulders with their
widespread and variable relatives. The taxonomic challenges of Cape
Erica are epitomised by the complex Cape “abietina/viscaria-clade”,
currently comprising at least 25 species. We reassess species boundaries
and patterns of regional endemism in this clade using a phylogeny
inferred from multiple nuclear ribosomal and plastid DNA sequences. We
show that the seven currently recognised subspecies of E. abietina
represent at least three independent, morphologically distinct lineages
with non-overlapping geographic distributions. We resurrect the name E.
grandiflora to include E. abietina subsp. aurantiaca and subsp.
perfoliosa; and provide a new name for E. abietina subspp. petraea:
Erica situshiemalis. The Cape Peninsula, including the natural world
heritage site Table Mountain National Park, can be attributed a further
endemic species, E. abietina, to add to its unique flora.
